entry.title: Python strings cheat sheet
entry.summary: This reference article covers the most common operations with strings.
entry.content:
This reference article covers the most common operations with strings.

Very short but important introPermalink

Strings in Python are immutable. That means we can never change (edit) a string. We always create a new one. Of course, we can then assign a newly created string to the same variable.

Everything is case sensitive unless stated otherwise. That means "Here" is NOT equal to "here", and "two" is NOT equal to "TWO", etc.

Joining stringsPermalink

We can join strings in Python with a + (addition) operator:

greeting = 'Hello ' + 'world!'
# 'Hello world!'

name = 'John'

'Hello ' + name
# 'Hello John'

bye = 'Bye '

bye + name
# 'Bye John'

We can join more than two strings, of course. But using + to join more than a few strings is inefficient. Especially in a loop, so never do that.

Instead, it's much better to use the join() method:

directions = ['up', 'right', 'down', 'left']

'>'.join(directions)
# 'up>right>down>left'

str.join(iterable) is a method of string. It takes one parameter - iterable (e.g. list, set etc.) and returns a new string.

It creates a new string by joining (concatenating) strings in iterable by string separator. The separator is the string on which we call the join() method (in the code above, it's ">".

Splitting stringPermalink

Sometimes we want to split one string into multiple using some separator. For that, we use the split() method:

names = 'John & Martin & Carla & Linda & Alena'
names.split(' & ')
# ['John', 'Martin', 'Carla', 'Linda', 'Alena']

split() needs one argument, separator, which it uses to split the string.

It also takes the optional argument maxsplit, limiting how many times to split the string. 

names = 'John & Martin & Carla & Linda & Alena'
names.split(' & ', 2)
# ['John', 'Martin', 'Carla & Linda & Alena']

Above, we call split() with the second argument 2, so it splits the string only twice. The remaining part is left untouched as the third item in the resulting list.

When we have multiple lines in our string (e.g. from a small file or other input), it's handy to use the splitlines() method, which splits a string at line boundaries, so the resulting list contains each line separately.

data = 'First line\nSecond line\nThird line'

data.splitlines()
# ['First line', 'Second line', 'Third line']

We could also use data.split('\n') but advantage of splitlines() is that it handles all the other line boundaries than just \n (doc).

Check if a string contains a substringPermalink

To check if a string contains some other string, we use the in operator:

numbers = 'one, two, three'
'two' in numbers
# True

'five' in numbers
# False

Check if a string starts with a prefixPermalink

To check if a string starts with some string, we use the startswith() function.

title = 'Here comes the sun'

title.startswith('Here')
# True

# Case sensitive so this will produce False
title.startswith('here')
# False

But what if we want to check if a string starts with one of the multiple prefixes?

startswith() also takes a tuple as a first argument so we can pass multiple prefixes to check against:

sentences = ['He is here', 'She is there', 
             'You are great', 'I am good']

# Print only sentences in third person
for s in sentences:
    if s.startswith(('He', 'She', 'It')):
        print(s)

# He is here
# She is there

startswith() also takes two optional parameters, start and end. We can use these to tell it where it should start to look for a prefix and where the search should end. Essentially it cuts our string before checking it:

'She is there'.startswith('is', start=4)
# True

end is not that useful for startswith but more for endswith().

Check if a string ends with a suffixPermalink

To check if a string ends with some strings, we use endswith(). It works the same as startswith().

title = 'Here comes the sun'

title.endswith('sun')
# True

We can also pass tuple as with startswith() and use start and end:

sentences = ['He is here', 'She is there', 
             'You are great', 'I am good']

# Print only sentences ending with 'eat' or 'good'
for s in sentences:
    if s.endswith(('eat', 'good')):
        print(s)
# You are great
# I am good

'You are great'.endswith('are', 0, 7)
# True

When we want to use end, we need to use start too - we use 0 when we don't want to ignore anything from the beginning of the string.

Count occurrences of a substringPermalink

When we need to know how many times substring occurs in our string, we use the count() method:

all_blue = 'I like blue shoes, blue shirts, blue hats'

all_blue.count('blue')
# 3

all_blue.count('green')
# 0

This method also takes start and end parameters. If provided, it looks for substring only within the range between start and end:

all_blue = 'I like blue shoes, blue shirts, blue hats'

all_blue.count('blue', 10, 30)
# 1

Length of a stringPermalink

To get the length of the string, that is, how many characters it has, we use the len() function:

len('hello')
# 5

Replacing part of a stringPermalink

Sometimes we want to replace part of the string with another string. We can use the replace(old, new) method:

all_blue = 'I like blue shoes, blue shirts, blue hats'

all_blue.replace('blue', 'green')
# 'I like green shoes, green shirts, green hats'

replace() takes one optional parameter count. By giving it this parameter, we can limit how many occurrences of the substring it should replace:

all_blue = 'I like blue shoes, blue shirts, blue hats'

all_blue.replace('blue', 'green', 1)
# 'I like green shoes, blue shirts, blue hats'

Convert string to lowercasePermalink

To make all characters in string lower case, we use the lower() method:

title = 'Here comes the sun'

title_lowercase = title.lower()
# 'here comes the sun'

Lowercasing a string is often helpful when dealing with substring (contains, starts with, ends with) or comparing, and we don't care about case sensitiveness. In this case, we make everything lower case and then do our operation.

Convert string to uppercasePermalink

We use the upper() method:

title = 'Here comes the sun'

title_uppercase = title.upper()
# 'HERE COMES THE SUN'

entry.title: Python's in operator
entry.summary: Where and how do we use the in operator in Python.
entry.content:
The in operator is ubiquitous in Python; it is used with strings, lists and other iterables to check if they contain a specific element.

in is a binary membership operator.

Binary means it uses two operandsâ€”one on the left and one on the right.

Membership means it checks if one operand is a member of the other operand. The in operator checks if its left operand is a member of its left operand.

Or, put more simply, it checks if its right operand contains its left operand. If it does, it returns True; otherwise, it returns False. We can use it only if an operand on the right is iterable.

Both left and right operands can be variables or values (constants).

Let's look at how we use it with different objects in Python.

StringsPermalink

The in operator can check if the string on the right contains the string on the left. In other words, we can use it to check if a string contains some substring.

s = 'Big blue sky'

'blue' in s
# outputs: True

b = 'blue'

b in s
# outputs: True

'red' in s
# outputs: False

The in operator is case-sensitive:

'big' in s
# outputs: False

'Big blue sky' does not contain big, but it does contain Big.

Few more examples:

j = 'joy of coding'

'din' in j
# outputs: True

'y of' in j
# outputs: True

Lists and other iterablesPermalink

The in operator also works with any iterable - lists, tuples, sets and others.

numbers = [2, 4, 6, 8]

4 in numbers
# outputs: True

5 in numbers
# outputs: False

Tuples:

t = ('a', 'b', 'c')

'a' in t
# outputs: True

'f' in t
# outputs: False

Sets:

colors = {'red', 'green', 'blue'}

'gr' in colors
# outputs: False

'red' in colors
# outputs: True

Please note that when we work with lists, sets, tuples (and dicts), the in operator checks if its left operand is an exact match to any item in the right operand. Unlike when we use the in with two strings, it is not looking for a substring.

DictsPermalink

dict is also iterable, but when we use the in operator with a dict, it only uses the dict's keys to check for membership.

It ignores the dict's values.

fruits = {
    'apple': 'red',
    'banana': 'yellow',
    'lime': 'green'
}

'red' in fruits
# outputs: False

'banana' in fruits
# outputs: True

So the in operator for dicts means: "Does the dict contains this key?"

not inPermalink

The in operator returns True if the left operand is a member of the right operand. not in does the exact opposite. It returns True if the left operand is NOT a member of the right operand.

Few examples:

s = 'Big blue sky'

'yellow' not in s
# outputs: True

'blue' not in s
# outputs: False

numbers = [2, 4, 6, 8]

1 not in numbers
# outputs True

2 not in numbers
# outputs False

fruits = {
    'apple': 'red',
    'banana': 'yellow',
    'lime': 'green'
}

'red' not in fruits
# outputs: True

'banana' not in fruits
# outputs: False
